Award.AwardTitle: Deciphering the Code for RNA Recognition by PPR Proteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The interpretation of genetic information by the molecular machinery inside cells requires highly specific interactions between protein, DNA, and RNA molecules. The ability to predict the nucleotide sequences bound by RNA and DNA binding proteins would accelerate understanding of the molecular networks that underlie organismal development and physiology, and would have broad application in basic research and biotechnology. However, it remains difficult to predict the RNA binding properties of most RNA binding proteins, or to design them to bind specified RNA sequences. This project focuses on a family of RNA binding proteins, the pentatricopeptide repeat (PPR) proteins, that holds special promise for the rational design of specified RNA binding properties and for the engineering of regulatory switches to control gene expression. PPR proteins consist of tandem repeating units that form a surface for binding RNA. PPR-RNA recognition is modular in nature: each repeat specifies binding to a particular RNA nucleotide via the combinatorial action of amino acids at two positions in the repeat. PPR proteins are found in all eucaryotic organisms, but the family is extraordinary for its size in the plant lineage, with >450 members in flowering plants. PPR proteins localize primarily to mitochondria and chloroplasts, where they influence the expression of RNAs encoded by the organellar genomes. As such, the PPR family has a profound impact on many organelle-dependent processes, including photosynthesis, respiration, and fertility. The goal of this project is to develop understanding of the basis for PPR-RNA recognition to the point that (i) the binding sites and functions of PPR proteins in crop plant genomes can be reliably predicted, and (ii) PPR proteins can be designed to achieve desired RNA sequence specificities. The ability to predict PPR binding sites and the functional consequences of that binding will be tested by engineering PPR proteins to regulate endogenous organellar genes that are distinct from their natural targets.

Broader Impacts: Anticipated outcomes would impact applied and basic biology by: (i) accelerating the assignment of functions to one of the largest gene families in plants; (ii) providing a set of switches with which to control mitochondrial and chloroplast gene expression, and thereby modulate photosynthesis, respiration, and plant fertility; and (iii) providing tools for targeting passenger proteins to specified RNA sequences in vivo. This funding will foster an international collaboration between laboratories in the US and Australia. The interdisciplinary and international nature of this research will provide a rich educational experience for one graduate and two undergraduate students. The undergraduates will take ownership of core components of the project, and will employ informatic, biochemical and genetic approaches. They will be mentored by the PI and graduate student in a program that will include weekly subgroup meetings tailored to their needs. Project content will also be incorporated into University-wide initiatives aiming to increase diversity in STEM disciplines.

This project is co-funded by Genetic Mechanisms in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, by Plant Genome Research Program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, and by the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interpretation of genetic information requires interactions between specific protein and RNA molecules. The ability to predict the RNA sequences bound by RNA-binding proteins and to design proteins to bind specified RNAs would have broad application in basic research and biotechnology. This project focused on a family of proteins, the pentatricopeptide repeat (PPR) proteins, that holds special promise for the rational design of RNA binding properties. PPR proteins bind RNAs in mitochondria and chloroplasts, and they are required for the production of the cellular machineries that carry out the essential processes of respiration and photosynthesis. PPR proteins consist of tandem repeating units that form a surface for binding RNA. At the start of this project, it was known that the RNA sequence specificity of PPR proteins is, to some extent, predictable and programmable, by virtue of an amino acid “code” that specifies which of the four nucleotides is bound by each PPR repeat. The goal of this project was to develop our understanding of this PPR code to the point that we can (i) reliably predict the repertoire of binding sites and functions of the PPR proteins in crop plant genomes, and (ii) design PPR tracts to achieve desired RNA sequence specificities and affinities for use in diverse applications. 

Summary of outcomes: We assigned functions to several proteins that are critical for plant viability, revealed that natural PPR proteins are less “predictable” than had been assumed, developed approaches for the rational design of molecular switches to modulate organelle gene expression, and provided tools for targeting passenger proteins to specified RNAs in vivo. These points are elaborated upon below.

i) Expanding the known functional repertoire of native PPR proteins.

We assigned functions to two members of the poorly understood PPR-SMR subfamily, showing that they activate translation and stabilize specific chloroplast RNAs. We showed that a member of the PLS subfamily, whose members generally specify sites of C- to-U RNA editing, acts as a blockade to degradation of a specific chloroplast mRNA. We developed and applied new methods to re-analyze several PPR proteins that were already the most thoroughly characterized of any members of the PPR family, and discovered additional functions and RNA ligands for each. Together, this body of work shows that PPR proteins can evolve to adopt a wide variety of functions, that they are less specific than had been assumed, and that additional functions remain to be discovered for the majority of “characterized” members of the PPR family.

ii) Contribution of the PPR code to RNA recognition by native PPR proteins.

We comprehensively analyzed the sequence specificity of the native protein PPR10, and found that the PPR code cannot account for a substantial fraction of the nucleotides that it recognizes. Additionally, we found that the PPR code cannot predict the diversity of RNA ligands recognized by several native PPR proteins in vivo. Together, these findings imply that many (probably most) native PPR proteins have idiosyncratic features that preclude accurate binding site predictions. Therefore, the goal of large-scale prediction of binding sites and functions of native PPR proteins is not realistic in the near future.

iii) RNA sequence specificity landscape of “designer” PPR proteins.

We designed synthetic PPR proteins built from consensus PPR motifs, and comprehensively analyzed the repertoire of RNA sequences they bind in vitro. Contrasting with results from native PPR proteins, the PPR code accurately predicted the sequence specificity landscapes of these designer proteins. Our results also elucidated how to design such proteins to maximize binding affinity while minimizing off-target binding. Finally, we showed that two designer PPR proteins expressed in chloroplasts bound with specificity to the intended RNA target. These results lay the foundation for the rational design of regulatory switches to control organelle gene expression and for targeting passenger proteins to specified RNAs.

 iv) Interplay between RNA folding and PPR binding. PPR proteins bind only to single-stranded RNA, yet they occupy RNAs in vivo that are predicted to form RNA structures. We explored the interplay between RNA folding and PPR binding by studying the binding of a model protein to RNAs with engineered structures of varying stability. The results showed that PPR binding is exquisitely sensitive to RNA structures that intrude on the binding site. This implies that mechanisms must exist in the cell to reorganize RNA structures and allow PPR binding.

 This work resulted in the publication of two invited review articles and five research articles thus far, with two additional articles undergoing revision after initial review.

 Training and outreach. One postdoctoral fellow, two PhD students, one MS student, and six undergraduates participated in this research, many of whom presented their findings at conferences. Some of these students served as mentors in a summer outreach program for underserved high school students, in which we used biochemical methods to analyze proteins in various foods.
